heading: 2.2 2.2 Levels of measurement
text: may may refresher material , extremely important familiar four levels measurement.Categorical: variables categories levels, analyzed mean levels proportionate. two types categorical variables:Nominal: categorical variable level variable named order (e.g., breeds dogs). Nominal variables can analyzed frequencies, modes, counts, percentages. Nominal variables two levels (generally coded 0 1, although jamovi can handle named levels), call special nominal variables either binary, dummy-coded, dichotomous nominal variables. example, binary variables coded yes absence presence.Nominal: categorical variable level variable named order (e.g., breeds dogs). Nominal variables can analyzed frequencies, modes, counts, percentages. Nominal variables two levels (generally coded 0 1, although jamovi can handle named levels), call special nominal variables either binary, dummy-coded, dichotomous nominal variables. example, binary variables coded yes absence presence.Ordinal: categorical variable level variable named order (e.g., ranks). can analyze ordinal variables frequencies percentages, like nominal variables, can also analyze using medians, minimum maximum values, ranges, percentiles.Ordinal: categorical variable level variable named order (e.g., ranks). can analyze ordinal variables frequencies percentages, like nominal variables, can also analyze using medians, minimum maximum values, ranges, percentiles.Continuous: variables proportionate intervals levels, meaning can analyzed mean, SD, variance. two types continuous variables (although purpose course simply call continuous variables):Interval: continuous variable intervals directly proportionate (e.g., distance 2-3 distance 5-6). can analyze interval variables using means, variances, standard deviations.Interval: continuous variable intervals directly proportionate (e.g., distance 2-3 distance 5-6). can analyze interval variables using means, variances, standard deviations.Ratio: continuous variable like internal variable can accommodate absolute zero, meaning zero actually possible (e.g., weight, temperature Kelvin, reaction time). can also analyze ratio variables means, variances, standard deviations, can also conduct arithmetic operations like fractions ratios.Ratio: continuous variable like internal variable can accommodate absolute zero, meaning zero actually possible (e.g., weight, temperature Kelvin, reaction time). can also analyze ratio variables means, variances, standard deviations, can also conduct arithmetic operations like fractions ratios.Note class, won’t ask differentiate interval ratio levels measurement differences two usually meaningful work. ’ll even find jamovi doesn’t differentiate two, either. heading: 2.3 2.3 Descriptive vs inferential statistics
text: basically two different types statistics:Descriptive statistics used summarize, organize, overall describe sample data. Typically, using measures central tendency (e.g., mean, median, mode), measures dispersion (e.g., range, standard deviation, variance), shape (e.g., skew, kurtosis). may also visualize data using tables graphs.Descriptive statistics used summarize, organize, overall describe sample data. Typically, using measures central tendency (e.g., mean, median, mode), measures dispersion (e.g., range, standard deviation, variance), shape (e.g., skew, kurtosis). may also visualize data using tables graphs.Inferential statistics use collect data sample see well sample infers things population sample comes . Typically, statistical tests like t-test, ANOVA, correlation, chi-square, regression, .Inferential statistics use collect data sample see well sample infers things population sample comes . Typically, statistical tests like t-test, ANOVA, correlation, chi-square, regression, .can visualize relationship population, sample, descriptive statistics, inferential statistics (see figure ). typically interested population interest may able collect data entire population budget, time, access, constraints. Therefore, typically sample population; ideally, randomly, types sampling methods available covered research methods. use descriptive statistics describe sample data, inferential statistics make generalizations population selected.Note typically use descriptive inferential statistics. However, studies may purely descriptive inference back population. typically always describe sample performing inferential statistics though.

terms familiar :-group/subject design: study, participants exposed single condition. words, different people condition.-group/subject design: study, participants exposed single condition. words, different people condition.Correlational research: study causality claimed; correlation infer causation! , however, one three necessary conditions infer causality. necessary insufficient alone condition.Correlational research: study causality claimed; correlation infer causation! , however, one three necessary conditions infer causality. necessary insufficient alone condition.Cross-sectional research: also called non-experimental research; IV manipulated random assignment. Divergent validity: correlations among two theoretically -related constructs (measurements) zero/null

heading: 6.1 7.1 Example of hypothesis testing
text:

Researchers observed aggressive behaviors6.

aggresive behaviors vs children watching passive behaviors) 
measured aggressive behaviors.

detail later.

heading: 6.1.4.1 Type 1 and 2 errors
text:
However, Type 1 (false positive) Type 2 (false negative) errors come play. Just get result automatically mean result 100% accurate. many things lead us inaccurate interpretation! Perhaps fluke, perhaps didn’t something correct study, perhaps effect actually exist.like use table discussing errors. far left column, results: statistically significant (p < .05) (p > .05)? top row, whether real world null alternative hypothesis true. reality, can never truly know whether null alternative hypothesis true. can best approximate understanding real world replication!Therefore, time get statistically significant result (p < .05), either made correct interpretation made Type 1 (false positive) error!Similarly, time get statistically non-significant results (p > .05) either made correct interpretation made Type 2 (false negative) error!
Another common mistake assume statistically significant results
mean null hypothesis false. However, can never know beyond 
certainty doubt whether significant result correct
interpretation; also making Type 1 error.

Similarly, common mistake assume non-significant results mean
null hypothesis true. never know sure whether null 
alternative true, case making Type 2
error.
